Source: IRENA 2022 (1025 GWh) × 1.05^4; validated against 2018 Island Electricity Data Book (585 GWh for 115 islands = 70% of IRENA 840 GWh)
Notes: R7: PUBLIC UTILITY demand only — EXCLUDES resort sector (1050 GWh off-grid). Total national electricity ~2250 GWh (1200 utility + 1050 resort). Roadmap 2400 GWh figure includes resorts. Triangulated: IRENA 2022 → 2026 projection. 2018 Data Book confirms ~840 GWh national utility.

Source: STELCO MD (edition.mv Aug 2025): Greater Malé +50 MW/5yr; PNG data: Malé+Hulhumalé peak 107 MW (~2023); 2018 Data Book: 97.6 MW (115 islands)
Notes: Triangulated: Greater Malé ~107 MW (PNG) + outer islands ~60-90 MW = ~170-200 MW national. STELCO MD confirms +50 MW/5yr trajectory. 200 MW is reasonable upper bound.

Source: 2018 Island Electricity Data Book (115 islands: 585 GWh / 97.6 MW peak / 8760h = 0.685); Malé LF=0.686
Notes: Empirical national LF=0.685. Old value 0.63 was back-calculated from rounded demand/peak, not measured. Island mean=0.585, Malé=0.686.

Source: IRENA 2018-2022: 840→1025 GWh = 5.1%/yr; STELCO MD (edition.mv Aug 2025): Malé ~9% but national avg ~5%
Notes: Validated: IRENA utility sector 5.1%/yr (2018-2022). Greater Malé grows faster (~9%) but outer islands slower (~2-3%). National weighted avg ~5%.

Source: With efficiency gains
Notes: ~1% reduction from BAU with grid efficiency

Source: Same as BAU; induced demand now modelled via price elasticity (L8)

Source: Wolfram et al. (2012) 'Modelling Electricity Demand in Developing Countries'; Burke et al. (2015) 'Global Energy Demand'
Notes: Short-run elasticity for SIDS. Range: -0.1 (inelastic/captive) to -0.5 (elastic/substitution available). Applied post-cable in Full Integration only.

Source: Platts Dec 2025; STO import data 2023-24
Notes: Maldives actual $0.82 (2023) / $0.87 (2024); $0.85 conservative midpoint

Notes: R4: Outer island diesel efficiency. Small gensets, partial loading, poor maintenance. 39% less efficient than Malé.

Source: IPCC 2006 Guidelines
Notes: From diesel combustion

Source: AIIB (2021) Maldives Solar Power Development P000377: $107.4M/36MW total project; solar component est. $1667-2500/kW. ASPIRE (World Bank 2015): $9.3M/6.5MW = $1431/kW. IPP pipeline $1000-1571/kW. IRENA RPGC 2024 SIDS range $800-1200/kW.

Source: IRENA (2024) Renewable Capacity Statistics: 1419 GW end-2023 + ~300 GW/yr additions

Source: IRENA RPGC 2024 §3.3: utility PV O&M 1-2% of CAPEX/yr globally; NREL ATB 2024: $16-18/kW-yr ≈ 1.1-1.2% at $1500/kW. 1.5% reflects island premium (salt corrosion; logistics).
Notes: 1.5% of CAPEX annually. Island environments require more frequent cleaning and corrosion mitigation.

Source: World Bank/Solargis Maldives Atlas
Notes: PVOUT ~1530 kWh/kWp; GHI 2000-2050 kWh/m2/yr

Notes: Manufacturing + transport + decommissioning

Notes: Total installed system cost (cells+inverter+BMS+installation+shipping). $120/kWh was cell/pack only; islands 2-3x higher than mainland turnkey

Source: Geographic + routing premium

Source: CIGRÉ TB 852 (2024) §6: submarine cable O&M typically 1.5-2.5% of CAPEX/yr; NorNed operational data ~2% (Statnett/TenneT annual reports); Basslink regulatory submissions ~2.2% (Amplitude/AER 2023).
Notes: 2% annual O&M as fraction of total cable CAPEX

Source: CIGRÉ TB 852 (2024): Recommendations for Testing DC Extruded Cable Systems; 40yr design life for XLPE-insulated HVDC cables
Notes: Design life for prequalification testing

Source: Härtel et al. (2017) EPSR 151:419-431; Vrana & Härtel (2023) EEM 2023; MISO MTEP24 Tables 2.4-1/2; Basslink ORC (Amplitude 2023 for AER). At 200MW scale upper range more likely due to fixed costs.
Notes: VSC-HVDC converter station pair. 200MW station pair total $640M ($480-800M). Per-MW costs higher at 200MW vs 1GW+ due to fixed valve hall/building/electrode costs. Only 3 manufacturers (Hitachi Energy; Siemens Energy; GE Vernova).

Source: CIGRÉ TB 815 (2021): Cable Systems Accessories; Worzyk (2009) Submarine Power Cables Ch.11; typical range $30-60M per landing station
Notes: Shore-end landing station cost — civil works; HDD/trenching; protection. Two ends required (India + Maldives).

Source: Two-terminal link: India + Maldives
Notes: Each HVDC link requires two shore-end landing stations

Source: ADB/IFC SIDS project finance norms: 3-5yr construction at 5-8% interest; typical IDC 10-20% of base CAPEX
Notes: Interest During Construction — capitalised financing cost added to project CAPEX. 15% of cable+converter+landing base cost.

Source: STELCO Grid Modernization Plan (via GoM Energy Roadmap Nov 2024); ADB POISED PCR 2023
Notes: Maldives-side grid reinforcement: Greater Malé substation upgrade; SCADA/protection systems; converter station integration. Not GoM-share-dependent.

Source: Engineering assumption — reef avoidance and bathymetry routing
Notes: Straight-line distance × 1.15 for submarine cable routing around reefs

Source: Least-cost engine: only 3 islands justify grid extension (Hulhumalé 7.5km, Vilingili 3.1km, Maradhoo 3.0km = 13.6km). Low=closest 2; High=5 islands.
Notes: MST analysis (network.py): 170/176 islands optimal as standalone solar+battery. Only 3 near-hub islands benefit from grid extension.

Source: NREL (2023) NREL/TP-5700-87184: subsea cable costs $200-600/m ($200k-600k/km) for 7-12kV marine systems; 33kV adds ~50-100% premium. Submarine Networks (2024): generic subsea power cable >$2.5M/km (HV, deep water). $1.5M/km reflects 33kV shallow-water (<50m) inter-island cable incl. trenching through coral substrate.
Notes: Shallow-water 33kV AC submarine cable. Short distances (3-8 km). Reef navigation adds complexity but shallow depth reduces cost vs deep-water HVDC.

Source: Model design choice — aligned with GoM Energy Roadmap 2024-2033 near-term infrastructure.

Notes: IEX day-ahead avg Rs 3.5-4.5/kWh ($0.04-$0.05) + cross-border premium

Source: India CERC Open Access Regulations (2024): inter-state transmission charge Rs 0.5-1.0/kWh ($0.006-0.012); cross-border wheeling adds ~Rs 0.3/kWh ($0.004). Total ~$0.01/kWh.
Notes: Cross-border wheeling charge included in delivered import price

Source: CEA CO2 Database 2023 (India); IEA WEO 2023
Notes: India national grid weighted-average emission factor

Category: # RE DEPLOYMENT — ENDOGENOUS (LCOE-driven + deployment ramp constraint)
# Solar+battery LCOE ($0.166/kWh) < Diesel LCOE ($0.299/kWh) from day one.
# Optimal outer-island RE = 100% as fast as deployable. Constraint = construction speed.
# PPA import ($0.07/kWh) < domestic solar → FI minimizes domestic RE post-cable.
# National RE = outer_share × outer_RE + male_share × male_RE (male_RE ≈ 4%).

Source: GoM pipeline 164 MW over ~3yr (55 MW/yr); SIDS logistics constraint. Low=conservative; High=aggressive mobilization.
Notes: Maximum solar capacity additions across all outer islands per year. Binding constraint: logistics, EPC capacity, financing absorption.

Source: 68.5 MW installed (2024) ÷ outer-island demand (~516 GWh) ≈ 10%
Notes: Starting RE share on outer islands in base year (2026). Pipeline already delivers first deployments.

Source: ZNES Flensburg: 18 MWp rooftop → 27.6 GWh/yr vs 684 GWh Malé demand = 4%. Low=5 MWp only; High=25 MWp incl. private.
Notes: Greater Malé max achievable RE without India cable. Land-constrained: no ground-mount possible.

Source: Model assumption — FI domestic RE cap (most demand met by cable import)
Notes: S1 domestic RE ceiling for India cable scenario. PPA $0.07 < solar $0.166 → cable import preferred.

Source: Model design — controls inclusion of inter-island cable costs
Notes: D-MO-07: Whether to include inter-island cable costs in grid scenarios (S2/S3/S5/S6/S7)

Category: # Greater Malé: 7.9% near-term (STELCO Master Plan) tapering to national rate
# Outer islands: 9% near-term (guesthouse boom) tapering to national rate

Source: STELCO Master Plan via Roadmap §4.1.1: Greater Malé 7.9%–9.6%/yr (Hulhumalé Phase 2/3 construction boom; Gulhifalhu industrial zone). Central value 10% reflects midpoint of STELCO range during peak construction.
Notes: R1: Greater Malé near-term demand growth rate. Includes Hulhumalé expansion. Tapers to long-term rate by Male Demand Saturation Year.

Source: Rate at saturation year (2035) before post-peak deceleration. Higher than national avg during construction tail. STELCO MD + Roadmap.
Notes: R1: Greater Malé rate at saturation year. After this, transitions to Male Post-Peak Growth Rate (decentralization).

Source: Census 2022 (NBS): Greater Malé 43% of national pop (Malé 38.6% + Hulhumalé 4.4% = 43%); HDC master plan projects continued urban primacy through 2060; Bertaud (2019) primacy model for island nations.
Notes: H17: Floor on Malé demand share. Even with strong decentralization, Greater Malé retains ~45% as capital, port, institutional center.

Source: Hulhumalé Phase 2 completion ~2030; Phase 3 ~2035. HDC timeline. R1: Changed from 2040 to 2035 (construction boom subsides earlier).
Notes: Year by which Greater Malé growth rate converges to long-term rate. After this year, transitions to Male Post-Peak Growth Rate.

Source: Post-construction-boom deceleration: density saturation (Bertaud 2019), water/power infrastructure constraints (MWSC), land scarcity (Census 2022: 65,000/km² Malé). Outer islands grow faster via decentralization policy (ARISE 2024, SAP 2019-2023).
Notes: H17: Greater Malé growth rate after saturation year. Lower than outer post-peak rate, driving share decline (decentralization).

Source: Roadmap §4.1.2: outer island growth driven by guesthouse tourism boom; energy access expansion (POISED/ASSURE). Central 7% is conservative vs 9% peak; reflects carrying capacity limits.
Notes: R2: Outer island near-term demand growth rate. Guesthouse tourism + energy access. Tapers to Outer Growth Long Term by Outer Growth Taper Year.

Source: Converges to national BAU rate once guesthouse expansion saturates (~2030). Tourism carrying capacity limits.
Notes: R2: Outer island long-term growth rate. Equal to national rate.

Source: Guesthouse boom peaks ~2028-2030; tourism capacity constraints bind. Roadmap implicit timeline.
Notes: R2: Year by which outer island growth converges to long-term rate.

Source: Post-2035 outer island electrification acceleration: ARISE Strategic Action Plan (2024) targets 100% RE access; decentralization policy (SAP 2019-2023); guesthouse economy matures beyond initial atolls. Rate exceeds Greater Malé post-peak, driving share rebalancing.
Notes: H17: Outer island growth rate after Male Demand Saturation Year. Higher than Malé post-peak, driving decentralization.

Source: Roadmap §4.1.3: fixed guest capacity (bed licenses); growth only from renovation + efficiency investments.
Notes: R3: Resort island demand growth. Off-grid; not in CBA scope. Informational for national emissions context.

Category: # Uninhabited islands near Malé can host solar farms connected by short cables.
# Breaks Malé 4% rooftop cap → 25% RE via near-shore; 65% with floating solar.

Source: GIS analysis: uninhabited islands within 10km of Malé (Thilafushi 0.43km² 6.9km; Gulhifalhu 0.45km² 5.7km; Funadhoo 0.15km²; Dhoonidhoo 0.16km²) → 1.82km² × 15% × 1MW/7m² = 104MW
Notes: Solar capacity on uninhabited islands near Malé (within 10km). Connected by short submarine cable.

Source: Engineering estimate: $5-8M for 5-10km shallow-water cable connecting solar farm to Malé grid; amortised over 104 MW
Notes: Per-MW cost of submarine cable connecting near-shore solar island to Malé grid

Source: Realistic timeline — permitting; EIA; cable manufacturing after initial outer-island RE deployment

Source: 3-year phased construction: land prep; cable laying; panel installation
Notes: Construction duration for near-shore solar farms

Notes: Floating solar PV capacity — aligned with GoM Roadmap 195 MW target

Source: IRENA (2020) Where Sun Meets Water: floating PV 10-25% cost premium over ground-mount. SIDS marine environment → 50% premium.

Source: After near-shore islands; requires proven floating PV technology in marine environment

Source: 5-year phased construction for large-scale floating PV on lagoon
